author: jsign
content:
Well, probably doesn't matter since it was reported above that this also happened in the browser.
Looking at the code of the sequencer (not an expert, just skimming), this can happen if when was your turn of contributing you didn't make a successful submission (being the contribution invalid, or I think also not submitting by the deadline (e.g: browser crashed, disconnected from network, or similar).
In that case, you're registered by the sequencer, but you will not be in the transcript (since you didn't make a contribution).

That error is returned if `has_contributed(...)` returns `true` (In https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/blob/master/src/storage.rs#L152-L194), which is an local SQL database in the sequencer. 
So probably both (irtvkjcl63 & arnacube) are in the SQL table, but clearly not in the transcript (since you don't see your user/addr in the ceremony transcript which is a separate thing). That `expire_contribution(...)` is called in these "error situations" where you won't be in the transcript.

Maybe it can be useful if the ceremony webpage, when looking at contributions, can also lookup in the SQL table; so this situation of "Is in the `contributors` table, but not in the transcript" can show some message "You got your turn, but no contribution was successful" instead of not showing anything which could be confusing.

author: carlbeek
content:
Yup, I agree with <@774033563732541451>'s analysis here, in order to prevent the ceremony from being DOS attacked, the sequencer stops people from contributions again if they tried to do so in the past and failed when they were handed the Powers of Tau.

We will flush this "Blacklist" at some point (to account for honest participants), but for now you should either wait for use annother account

author: carlbeek
content: The subgrop size (`r=52435875175126190479447740508185965837690552500527637822603658699938581184513`) for BLS12-381 is ~255 bits so adding more entropy than that is superfluous assuming it has no modulo bias with respect to `r`.  How the bias plays into this depends on the interface you are using (for example, the hosted interface at `ceremony.ethereum.org` stretches then entropy to 384 bytes to ensure cryptographically small modulo bias). So depending on the interface you use, ideally at least ~255 bits, but more (may) help reduce bias.
